moves.1. e4: Kings Indian Attack, within the limited knowledge I possess.
moves.5... e6 6. Nbd2: I know little variations of the KIA... thus I use this one Nbd2, helps in center.
moves.6... Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. a3 Qc7 9. b3 b5 1: The atmosphere in the DMZ tightens.
moves.11. Rc1 Bb7 12. c3: Hoping to find an opening at the Black Queen.
moves.15. Rfe1 Bf8 16. bxc5 dxc5 17. c4: This gives White a "go" position ( a dead space at d4); clogs the middle.
moves.17... Nd4: ... it gets filled by a Knight...
moves.18. Qf1 Nxf3+ 19. Bxf3 Rd6: Black is preparing to stack rooks and hit the weak pawn at d3; White figures on defending with the B.
moves.20... Red8: Out of thin air a R-Q alignment on d6-e7 shows up and is a prime target for the Bishop!  and there is free P at e5.... Should White take or make some preparations before striking?
moves.21... Qa5 22. Bxd6 Qxd2: White gets the R for a N and P ...   and can go for a series of trades.
moves.28... Kxg7 29. Be5+ f6 30. Bb2: Getting to the end game; every Pawn is valuable.
moves.30... Bb3 31. Re3 Rxe3 32. fxe3: R for R, and am hoping for B for B.
moves.32... c4: Even though White is ahead Rook to Bishop, White is unsure about stopping the connected two Pawns on the queen-side and the always nasty "Two Bishops".
moves.33. Kf2 Bd6 34. Kf3 Be5: Giving White the opportunity to take away the "Two Bishops" and get further pieces off the board.
moves.35. Bxe5 fxe5: There is the B for B.  Now to tighten up the middle.
moves.36. h4 Kf6 37. g4: White is hoping to grind this one down.
moves.37... h6 38. Ke4: The Black King is getting "confined to quarters".
moves.38... Ba4 39. Kd5 Bb3 40. Kd6: Trying to take another P, but can't get Black to cooperate.
moves.40... e4 41. Kc5 Ba4: Surprising to White is that the Black Bishop appears to be trapped and can't get out of this corner.
moves.42. Kb4: White closes quarters on the 'trapped' Bishop, which should lead to further losses for White.  At this point Black resigns noting no reason to 'drag this out'.
